questions.text: Which of the following uterine body to cervix ratios is most consistent with a normal prepubertal girl?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Uterine Body: Cervix

Physiology

In prepubertal girl

1:2

Uterus is small and cervix is longer than the body

At puberty

2:1

The body is bigger than the cervix

During reproductive years

3:1 or even 4:1

The body of the uterus continues to grow by the action of estrogen.

Postmenopausal women

1:2

Uterus is atrophic, body is smaller than the cervix

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a painless swelling in the inguinal area and labia majora. The swelling is present for several months and gradually increases in size. On examination, the swelling is soft and fluctuant. An ultrasound is ordered, which shows a fluid-filled sac extending into the labia majora. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrocele of the Canal of Nuck

questions.correct_answer: B. Hydrocele of the Canal of Nuck

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for an annual check-up. She is asymptomatic but has a history of occasional pelvic pain. A 4 cm cyst is identified adjacent to the right ovary during a routine pelvic ultrasound. The cyst appears to have thin, smooth walls and an anechoic center. What is the most likely diagnosis and recommended management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Ovarian cyst; initiate oral contraceptive pills for suppression.

options.label: B
options.text: Paraovarian cyst; schedule for surgical removal due to potential complications.

options.label: C
options.text: Paraovarian cyst; monitor with follow-up ultrasounds if asymptomatic.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydatid of Morgagni; immediate surgical removal due to high risk of malignancy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Paraovarian cyst; monitor with follow-up ultrasounds if asymptomatic.
questions.explanation:
Paraovarian Cyst

Origin

Paratubal and paraovarian cysts are typically non-neoplastic, originating from paramesonephric duct remnants or mesothelial inclusion cysts.

Common Types

Most common type is the hydatid of Morgagni, usually pedunculated from the fimbria.

Neoplastic Cysts

Rare and usually benign, such as cystadenomas or cystadenofibromas, resembling ovarian tumors histologically.

Symptoms

May mimic ovarian cyst symptoms and can rarely lead to complications like hemorrhage, rupture, or torsion.

Imaging Techniques

Transvaginal sonography and MRI are used but have limitations in distinguishing paraovarian from ovarian pathology.

Management
  • Typically involves surgical removal by cystectomy or drainage and fulguration of the cyst wall, especially if symptomatic or found incidentally during surgery.
  • If asymptomatic, monitoring with periodic ultrasounds is appropriate unless symptoms develop or complications arise.

Solid Paraovarian Masses

Solid Tumors
  • Include leiomyomas and rare tumors of probable Wolffian origin.
  • Usually asymptomatic and found during routine pelvic exams.

Imaging for Solid Tumors

Sonography and MRI help visualize these masses, but distinguishing between benign and malignant tumors is difficult, often requiring surgical removal.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman presents with recurrent pregnancy loss. She has had three first-trimester miscarriages over the past two years. Her menstrual cycles are regular, and she has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, no abnormalities are noted. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is most likely associated with her recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.explanation:
Müllerian Uterine Anomaly

Description

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Septate Uterus (Option B)

Incomplete resorption of the septum between the Müllerian ducts, resulting in a fibrous septum within the uterine cavity.
  • Recurrent first-trimester miscarriages, Infertility.
  • D/D: Bicornuate uterus has an intercomual angle >105 degrees during hysterosalpingography.

Hysteroscopic metroplasty to remove the septum.

Bicornuate Uterus (Option A)

Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to a heart-shaped uterus with two cavities.

Higher incidence of infertility, endometriosis, and dysmenorrhea.

Metroplasty in severe cases. Often managed conservatively.

Didelphys Uterus (Option C)

Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts, two separate uteri, and often two cervices.

Preterm labor, Menstrual irregularities. 

Managed conservatively, Metroplasty if symptomatic.

Unicornuate Uterus - Noncommunicating (Option D)

Partial development of one Müllerian duct, resulting in a single-horned uterus.
  • Cyclic pelvic pain may be misdiagnosed as an adnexal mass.
  • Ectopic pregnancy, Preterm labor 

Prophylactic cerclage placement or progesterone supplementation to prevent preterm birth.

Arcuate Uterus

Mild indentation at the top of the uterine cavity due to minor incomplete resorption of the septum.

Generally asymptomatic and normal reproductive outcomes.

Reassurance and conservative management.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the fallopian tubes? The medial ⅔ of the fallopian tube is supplied by the uterine artery. Ligation of the uterine artery does not lead to ischemia of the fallopian tube. The interstitial portion of the fallopian tube acts as a physiological sphincter. Infection with N. gonorrhoeae causes blockage at the cornual end of the fallopian tube.

A 28 y/o woman presents with pelvic pain and discomfort. On examination, you note that her uterus is retroverted. Which of the following ligaments, if weakened, is most likely to contribute to this condition?
questions.explanation:
Uterine Ligaments

Ligament

Function

Associated disease

Broad Ligament (Option C)
  • Double layers of peritoneum that extend from the lateral walls of the uterus to the pelvic walls.
  • Contain the fallopian tube, ovarian ligament, and round ligament.
  • Broad ligament cysts
  • Endometriosis

Round Ligament (Option B)
  • Extends from the uterine cornu through the inguinal canal to the labia majora. (do not significantly contribute to uterine support)
  • Round ligament varicosities
  • Pain during pregnancy due to stretching.

Uterosacral Ligament (Option A)
  • Help to support the uterus, prevent it from being forced down by intra-abdominal pressure
  • Antevert the uterus by pulling the cervix back.
  • Contain sympathetic & parasympathetic nerves.
  • Uterosacral ligament endometriosis.
  • Retroverted/ tilted back when weakened.

Mackenrodt's Ligaments
  • AKA transverse cervical ligaments or cardinal ligaments.
  • Consist of vessels and connective tissue.
  • Parametritis

Ovarian Ligament (Option D)
  • Connects the ovary to the uterus.
  • Stabilizes the position of the ovary.
  • Ovarian torsion.
  • Ovarian cysts or tumors

Suspensory Ligament of the Ovary
  • Extends from the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall.
  • Contains the ovarian vessels and nerves.
  • Ovarian vein syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the broad ligament?
questions.explanation:
Broad Ligament

Definition

Two winglike structures extending from the lateral uterine margins to the pelvic sidewalls, each formed by a double layer of peritoneum

Function

The broad ligament helps stabilize the uterus's position within the pelvic cavity.

Contents
  • Fallopian tube - Upper portion: The peritoneum that folds over the fallopian tube is the mesosalpinx.
  • Round ligament - Anteriorly: The peritoneum surrounding the round ligament is called the mesoteres. (Option A)
  • Ovarian ligament - Posterior fold: The peritoneum that encompasses the ovarian ligament is known as the mesovarium.
  • Vestigial structures of Wolffian body - Epoophoron and paroophoron.
  • Vestigial structure of Wolffian duct - Gartner's duct.
  • Ureter. (Option B)
  • Uterine vessels.
  • Pelvic nerves.
  • Parametrial lymph node.
  • Pelvic cellular tissue condensed to form Mackenrodt 's ligament.
  • lnfundibulopelvic ligament (suspensory ligament of the ovary) - Outer border of the broad ligament. (Option C)

Blood Supply
  • Uterine artery, courses through the base of the broad ligament and supplies the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
  • Ovarian artery, enters the broad ligament through the infundibulopelvic ligament and supplies the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

questions.text: Select which all statements are true from the following: For painless labor: T8 block For instrumental delivery: Pudendal nerve block Pain during early labor: T8-T10 Pain during late labor: S2-S4
questions.explanation:
Sympathetic nerve supply

T11-L1 of hypogastric plexus

Parasympathetic nerve supply

S2-S4 via pelvic plexus

Afferent nerves supplying uterus

T10-L1

questions.text: A 45 Y/o woman presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain. A pelvic examination reveals a suspicious lesion on the cervix, and a biopsy confirms cervical cancer. Which of the following lymph nodes are the first to get involved in the spread of cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Upper Portion of Uterus
  • Fundus and superior uterine body: Aortic (pre and para) lymph nodes (Option B)
  • Cornu: superficial inguinal lymph nodes

Uterine Body

External iliac lymph nodes (Option C)

Cervix and Upper ⅔ Vagina

Paracervical and parametrial lymph nodes to Internal iliac lymph nodes (Option D)

Lower ⅓ Vagina

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes (Option A)

questions.text: Which of the following branches of the uterine artery primarily supplies blood to the Endometrium?

Match the following male reproductive organs with their homologous female reproductive organs. 1. Testes A. Bartholin's glands 2. Penis B. Ovaries 3. Scrotum C. Clitoris 4. Bulbourethral glands D. Labia majora
questions.explanation:
Homologous Structures

Testes - Ovaries
  • Derived from the undifferentiated gonadal ridge in the embryo.
  • Function as the primary reproductive organs, producing gametes and hormones.

Penis - Clitoris
  • Develops from the genital tubercle.
  • Sensitive erectile tissues involved in sexual arousal.

Scrotum - Labia majora
  • Develops from the labioscrotal swellings from mesoderm layer.
  • Serve as protective structures for the reproductive organs.

Penile urethra - Labia minora

Develops from the urethral folds.

Bulbourethral glands - Bartholin's glands
  • Develops from the urogenital sinus, which is part of the endodermal tissue.
  • Both glands secrete mucus to lubricate.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with swelling and tenderness in the area adjacent to her vaginal opening. Physical examination reveals a tender, fluctuant mass at the posterior part of the vestibule, near the fourchette. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Vestibule
  • Almond-shaped area enclosed by:
    1. Laterally - Hart line (demarcation between the vulva vestibule and the labia minora)
    2. Medially - hymen
    3. Anteriorly - clitoral frenulum
    4. Posteriorly - Fourchette
  • Perforated by six openings:
    1. Urethra,
    2. Vagina,
    3. Two Bartholin gland ducts
    4. Ducts of two largest paraurethral (Skene) glands

Bartholin Glands (Option A)
  • Bilateral glands, 0.5 to 1 cm diameter, located deep to vestibular bulb and bulbospongiosus muscle.
  • Each gland has a 1.5 to 2 cm duct opening distally to hymeneal ring at 5 and 7 o'clock on vestibule.

Minor Vestibular Glands

Shallow glands with simple mucin-secreting epithelium, open along Hart line.

Paraurethral Glands (Skene) (Option B)
  • Arborization of glands with small ducts opening into urethra, predominantly along its interior.
  • Largest glands are Skene glands, with ducts near urethral meatus.

Urethral Meatus (Option C)

Midline opening in vestibule, 1 to 1.5 cm below pubic arch, located above vaginal opening.

questions.text: What distinguishes the anatomical internal os from the histological internal os?

options.label: A
options.text: The anatomical IO marks the transition between cervical and endometrial mucosa, while the histological IO marks the uterine isthmus.

options.label: B
options.text: The anatomical IO separates the uterine isthmus from the uterine corpus, while the histological IO marks the cervical canal.

options.label: C
options.text: The anatomical IO is visible during hysteroscopy, unlike the histological IO which is not.

options.label: D
options.text: The anatomical IO aligns precisely with the histological IO.

questions.correct_answer: B. The anatomical IO separates the uterine isthmus from the uterine corpus, while the histological IO marks the cervical canal.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Anatomical Internal Os

Histological Internal Os

Location

Marks the narrowing of the uterine cavity, separating the uterine isthmus from the body of the uterus. (Option B)

Refers to the transition between the cervical mucosa and the endometrial mucosa. (Vs Option A)

Visibility in Hysteroscopy

Not always clearly visible due to its anatomical nature. (Vs Option C)

More readily identifiable during hysteroscopy. (Vs Option C)

Distinct Feature

Anatomical landmark defining the upper limit of the uterine isthmus region. (Vs Option A)

Often termed the "internal cervical os," delineating the cervical canal from the uterine cavity. (Option B)

Histological Alignment

May not coincide with the histological internal os due to different histological characteristics of the uterine isthmus region. (Vs Option D)

Does not always align with the anatomical internal os, as the isthmus region has distinct histological features.

(Vs Option D)

questions.text: During a routine prenatal examination at 20 weeks gestation, a physician observes that the external cervix appears reddened and more prominent than usual. The patient is asymptomatic. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.explanation:
Endocervix

Ectocervix
  • Bound above by the internal os and below by the external os.
  • Lined by single layer of high columnar ciliated epithelium with spindle-shaped nuclei.
  • Appears red
  • Part of cervix near the vagina
  • Lined by stratified columnar epithelium
  • Appears pink.
  • Experiences changes in the pH of the secretion in different menstrual cycle phases.

Squamocolumnar Junction
  • Forms during embryogenesis as squamous epithelium migrates upward from urogenital sinus, replacing Müllerian epithelium near external cervical os.
  • Distinguishes pink, smooth squamous epithelium from red, velvety columnar epithelium around external cervical os.
  • Incomplete migration may result in SCJ forming in upper vaginal fornices, linked to in utero DES exposure.

Columnar Epithelium

Appears glandular but lacks true glands with acini and ducts.

Location and Hormonal Variations
  • SCJ location varies with age and hormonal changes.
  • Eversion during estrogenic states and regression during low-estrogen periods like menopause.

Squamous Metaplasia

Triggered by estrogen-induced glycogen formation and dominance of lactobacilli, replacing columnar with squamous epithelium.

Transformation Zone (TZ)
  • Junction between new & old SCJ.
  • Site where squamous epithelium forms.
  • Known for development of nearly all cervical neoplasias, particularly affecting younger women due to vulnerability to HPV effects.

questions.text: Match the type of cyst with the correct description of it. Types of Cysts Description 1. Functional cyst A. A mucus-filled cyst on the cervix 2. Gartner’s cyst B. Forms due to remnants of the Wolffian duct 3. Skene’s cyst C. Located near the urethra in females 4. Nabothian cyst D. Commonly occurs in the ovaries
questions.explanation:
Type of Cyst

Description

Details

Functional Cyst

Fluid-filled sacs that form on the ovaries, typically during the menstrual cycle.

 

 
  •  2 Types:
    1. Follicular cysts form due to hormonal dysfunction prior to ovulation, leading to expansion of the follicular antrum with serous fluid.
    2. Corpus luteum cysts form due to excessive hemorrhage from the vascular corpus luteum following ovulation.
  • High-dose combination oral contraceptives (COCs) suppress ovarian activity and protect against cyst development.
  • Surgical excision is considered for large, persistent cysts or smaller ones causing persistent symptoms. Usually benign and not cancerous.

Gartner’s Cyst

Forms from remnants of the Wolffian duct
  • Located along vaginal walls
  • Can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia if large
  • Treatment may involve surgical removal if symptomatic

Skene’s Cyst

Located near the urethra in females, formed from the Skene’s glands.
  • Involved in lubrication of the urethral opening. Usually presents as a urethral diverticulum.
  • Cysts here can cause urinary problems, pain, or discomfort.
  • Treatment may include antibiotics for infection or surgical drainage/removal if necessary.

Nabothian Cyst

Mucus-filled cysts that occur on the cervix.
  • Form when mucus-producing glands in the cervix are covered by skin cells, trapping the mucus.
  • Generally harmless, asymptomatic and often found during routine pelvic exams.
  • No treatment is typically required unless they cause significant symptoms, in which case they can be drained or removed.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman presents with difficulty sitting and walking due to the pain. On physical examination, a tender, fluctuant mass is palpated in the right inferior labia majora. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Aspiration of the cyst with a syringe and needle

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate referral for surgical excision of the gland

options.label: D
options.text: Incision and drainage followed by placement of a Word catheter

questions.correct_answer: D. Incision and drainage followed by placement of a Word catheter

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the role of Döderlein bacilli in the female reproductive system?

options.label: A
options.text: Pathogenic bacteria causing recurrent urinary tract infections

options.label: B
options.text: Involved in estrogen synthesis in the vaginal epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Helps maintain acidic vaginal pH and protects against infections

options.label: D
options.text: Primarily responsible for the production of vaginal mucus

questions.correct_answer: C. Helps maintain acidic vaginal pH and protects against infections

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the effect of estrogen on the vaginal epithelium and flora in women of different ages?

options.label: A
options.text: Prepubertal girls→high estrogen levels→thick vaginal epithelium & increase in lactobacilli.

options.label: B
options.text: Postmenopausal women→low estrogen levels→thin vaginal epithelium & decrease in Lactobacilli.

options.label: C
options.text: Prepubertal girls→low estrogen levels→thick vaginal epithelium and an acidic vaginal pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Reproductive-age women→high estrogen levels→thin vaginal epithelium & decrease in Lactobacilli.

questions.correct_answer: B. Postmenopausal women→low estrogen levels→thin vaginal epithelium & decrease in Lactobacilli.
questions.explanation:
Prepuberty

Low estrogen levels
  • Thin vaginal epithelium and
  • Lower prevalence of lactobacillus (Options A&C)

Puberty

High estrogen levels
  • Thick vaginal epithelium and
  • Higher prevalence of lactobacillus (Option D)

Postmenopausal women not on hormone replacement

Low estrogen levels
  • Thin vaginal epithelium and
  • Lower prevalence of lactobacillus (Option B)

Postmenopausal women on hormone replacement

High estrogen levels
  • Thick vaginal epithelium and
  • Higher prevalence of lactobacillus

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has never had a menstrual period but reports normal breast development and body hair growth. On physical examination, she is noted to have a shallow vaginal pouch measuring 2 cm in length. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Complete Vaginal Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)

Definition

Developmental defects of the Müllerian ducts result in the absence of structures derived from them, namely the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.

Clinical Presentation
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Examination: Shallow vaginal pouch measuring 1–2 cm in length.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging: Pelvic and abdominal ultrasound, 3D ultrasound, and MRI.
  • Karyotyping

Differential Diagnoses

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) - Karyotype is 46 XY, and testosterone levels are typically in the male range.

Treatment
  • Nonsurgical methods: Frank's method of dilation.
  • Surgical vaginoplasty.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl with cyclic lower abdominal pain and increasing abdominal distension over the past several months. She has not yet had her first menstrual period. Physical examination reveals normal secondary sexual characteristics, but a bulging, bluish membrane is seen at the introitus. An ultrasound reveals a large collection of fluid in the vagina and uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Hymen Type

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Imperforate
(Option A)
  • Menarche with cyclic pain, and amenorrhea.
  • Abdominal pain.
  • Cryptomenorrhea: Menstrual blood is produced but not expelled from the body.
  • Hematocolpos: Bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus. 
  • Hematometra: Accumulation of menstrual blood in the uterus.
  • Hematosalpinx: Accumulation of blood in the fallopian tubes.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Transverse Vaginal septum -
    • Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts and urogenital sinus.
    • A fibrous band of tissue at various levels (low, mid, or high) that divides the vagina horizontally.
    • Normal external genitalia; vaginal examination reveals a membrane or band within the vagina on palpation.
    • Mx: Surgical resection of the septum.
  • Incision and drainage.
  • Avoid needle aspiration, as this can lead to infection.

Microperforate (Option B)

Very small opening, which may cause menstrual irregularities or difficulty with tampon use.

Surgical incision followed by excision of the hymen.

Septate (Option D)
  • Band of tissue dividing the vaginal opening
  • Dyspareunia.
  • If one side of a septate vagina is obstructed, it can lead to mucocolpos or hematocolpos.

Excision

Cribriform (sieve)(Option C)

Multiple small openings allow for menstrual flow but often cause discomfort or difficulties with intercourse.

  

Annular
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Difficulty in tampon placement/ intercourse.
  

Naviculare (boatlike)
